Title: Release of semi-refrigerated liquefied highly flammable propylene gas during loading of marine LPG carrier
LessonsLearned:
<b>Immediate lessons: </b>Site tests conducted by manufacturers of
loading arm and BP specialists identified hydraulic leakage
problems within hydraulic system and probable absence of shear pin as
causes of ERC release. HSE inspector identified action of operators in
failing to follow correct procedures when setting ERC arming
arrangement as contributory factor to ERC release. Gas detection system
found to be non operational.<br><b><br>Measures to prevent recurrence: </b>Hardware - Engineering modifications made to hydraulic system for ERC mechanism to prevent reoccurrence of spurious pressurisation of lock and life line.                                                                                                                Operators - Modifications to operating instructions for operation of ERC mechanism on loading arms.                       Maintenance - Implementation of full written maintenance and inspection programme.                                              Training - Implementation of new training/refresher training arrangements for operators/technicians.<br><br><b>Measures to mitigate consequences: </b>Location of ESD switches reviewed at jetty head of Jetties 2 and 3.                                                                          Location of emergency switch to isolate power in jetties central office/mess rooms reviewed.                                    Location of ESD pendant on ship reviewed with respect to access.                                                                          Type and location of fixed gas detection system at jetties 2 and 3 reviewed.<br><br><b>Useful references: </b>See enclosed:- BPOGR Ltd: Investigation Report                                                                                                      HSE Investigation Report                                                                                                                                           Map of Grangemouth Docks                                                                                                                                      HSE letter to BROGR Ltd<br><br><br>
EmergencyResponce_Descr: Ships crew anticipated ship emergency shutdown system (ESD) and operated water spray system. Jetty operators anticipated jetty ESD at jetty roof. BP Chemicals Ltd BP fire station and shift team. Leader informed of incident by radio. Mess room advised to isolate electrics because of advancing vapour cloud. Shoreside fire pumps at jetty 3 primed for use but not activated because of ships deluge system. Central Regional Fire Brigade arrived after cloud harmlessly dispersed.<br><b><br></b>Gas detection system failed to alarm,found to be inoperable after incident.<br><br>Official action taken - legal action: <br>Three Improvement notices issued to BP:-                                                                                                                 <br>1. Inadequate maintenance.                                                                                                                                       <br>2. Inadequate training.                                                                                                                                                <br>3. Inadequate monitoring arrangements.<br><br>Official action taken - other official action: <br>Liaison with Woodfield to ensure other UK users with similar ERC mechanism are aware of problem and undertake remedial action. Liaison with other CHID Inspectors.<br><br><b>Discussion about response: </b><br>BPOGR Ltd produced Action Plan following Design Review                                                                                      Meeting with Woodfields / MIB Ltd for modifications to ERC mechanism on loading arms.                                        BP complied with improvement notices issued by HSE regarding training, maintenance and monitoring arrangements and incorporated recommendations made in HSE letter is their final accident report.<br><br><br>

Reasons.ItemDescription: Substances involved: greater than 5% of quantity in Column 3 of Annex I
Injury to persons: >= 1 fatalities, >= 6 hospitalizing injuries etc.
Immediate damage to the environment (according to Annex VI)

AccidentDescription: Uncontrolled release of approx 8.5 tonnes of semi- refrigerated liquefied highly flammable PROPYLENE gas during loading of marine LPG carrier. When emergency release coupling (ERC) on the liquid loading arm abruptly parted without prior closure of the isolating ball valve sequence.This dangerous occurrence caused the function of a vapour cloud which obscured the ship and spread South westwards along the jetty and Eastern channel before dispersing harmlessly.<br><br>13.30 Loading arm connected to ship at both liquid and vapour return line connectors.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <br>14.30 Loading commenced ??? of 100 tonnes / hour&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <br>15.00 Loading rate increased to the agreed 300 tonnes / hour&nbsp; <br>18.54 ERC on liquid loading arm parted with ball valve opened. <br>18.54 + 30 secs Ship ESD system activated and deluge systems operated. BP jetty operators situated in jetty ??? adjacent to ??? arms, on hearing ERC parting, went to investigate and met by white cloud of propylene. They ran along jetty road to escape and activated jetty ESD system at the jetty roof to shutdown loading pumps and emergency stop valves.&nbsp; <br>19.00 Gas cloud digressed sufficiently for jetty operators to approach jetty head control cabinet and close connected ball valves and separate vapour return line EKC by activation of ERC manual control. See map of jetty area.<br><br>Meteorological conditions - Remarks: <br>Conditions breezy / south easterly wind<br>Wind speed: 0.15<br>Wind direction: 140<br>Wind stability: N/K<br>Temperature: 18.00<br><br>

No: 115-07-1), flash point, -18°C, boiling point, -46.6°C, amount involved: approx 8.5 tonnes released.<b><br><br></b>Actual loss 2 8.Ste propylene. Potential loss in LPG gas carrier hold approx 1200 te.  ???storage n/k<br><br><b><br></b>

Causes_Description:
<b></b>(1) Leakage of hydraulic fluid through a previously unidentified route into part of the curcuit which triggers the ERC release mechanism resulted in a sufficient build up of pressure into the ERC liquid line to cause ERC release without the full isolating sequence being completed,COUPLED WITH <br>(2) Apparent absence of the shear pin in the liquid line ERC whose role has been found to be mandatory to the security if the hydraulic system since identification of above hydraulic problems. IN ADDITION <br>(3) Operators failure to follow the correct procedures for lining up the arming arrangement on the vapour line ERC after experiencing problems in manouvering the loading arm prior to loading is considered to have contributed to activation of the ERC mechanism, by contributing to the build up of pressure in the ERC liquid release line.<br>&nbsp; <br><b>Remarks: <br></b>Inadequate
leadership/monitoring - adequacy in training in operation of loading
booms had not been formally measured. Inadequate training - as
maintenance / operation of loading booms for preventors and
technicians. Inadequate work standards - no identification of safety
critical equipment, on which to build a comprehensive inspection plan.
Inadequate monitoring - of loading operations by operators, failure of
gas detection system.<br><br>

CausesHumans.ItemDescription: operator health (includes ailments, intoxication, death, etc.)
wilful disobedience/failure to carry out duties

CausesExternals.ItemDescription: utilities failure (electricity, gas, water, steam air, etc.)

Consequence_Description: Material loss of approx 8.5 tonnes of propylene gas at a cost of 21,200 US dollars. Demurrage for LPG carrier at a cost of 26,700 US dollars. Additional pilotage for LPG carrier at a cost of 330 US dollars.<br><b><br></b>People - Remarks: <br>Off site population at ??? immediate vicinity include ships crew, 200m west of J3 30 employees at Ross Chemicals Ltd, task papers;                                                                                                                                                         Other populations at risk dependent on wind direction include operators at BP Chemicals Ltd farms, 100 m east of J3 and employees at South ports Authority offices, 300m north of J2 / J3.<br><br>Discussion of consequences: <br>Consequences of ignition of propylene vapour cloud:-                                                                                                <br>1. Fatalities to jetty operators and ships crew.                                                                                                             <br>2. Damage to jetty facilities and depending on extent of vapour cloud damage to ships berth at other BP jetty facilities, Ross Chemicals berth and other dock users.                                                                                                <br>3. Shutdown of Grangemouth jetties for essential repairs impacting on production at BP exploration facilities at ??? (impacting as N Sea production, BP Oil Grangemouth Refinery and BP Chemicals, Grangemouth).<br><br>Affected Area: installation<br><br><br>

EmergencyResponses.Effect: drenching systems (water sprays, monitors, etc.); plant emergency shut-down procedures; management/organization review; plant emergency shut-down procedures; alarms/sirens sounded; internal emergency teams (fire, ambulance, etc.)
